prompt.p: Endothelial cells line all blood vessels and these play a central role in preventing unwanted thrombosis. The endothelium provides an effective barrier between the thrombogenic subendothelial cells and the blood coagulation factors
What is the function of thrombomodulin?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Involved in the control of thrombin
Released from the activated platelet and causes vasoconstriction

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Involved in the control of thrombin) is Correct. Agents produced by endothelium include:

ul.li: Thrombomodulin: this is a protein involved in the control of thrombin.
Heparin sulphate: this is a naturally occurring heparin that leads to inhibition of thrombin.
Enzymes: these degrade platelet-derived molecules, such as adenosine triphosphate (ADP), the latter encouraging platelets to aggregate.
Prostacyclin and nitric oxide (NO), which are potent inhibitors of platelet aggregation, discouraging platelets from sticking to the vessel wall.

modalFeedback.p:
Option A (Encourages platelet aggregation) is Incorrect. ADP encourages platelet aggregation.
Option B (Inhibits thrombin) is Incorrect. Heparin sulphate inhibits thrombin.
Option D (Potent inhibitor of platelet aggregation) is Incorrect. Prostacyclin and NO are potent inhibitors of platelet aggregation.
Option E (Released from the activated platelet and causes vasoconstriction) is Incorrect. Thrombomodulin is present on endothelial cells.
